captions.text: What are we really made of?

[Frank Close]
The atoms that we're made of have
whirling around a big bulky nucleus.

[Brian Cox]
The universe is made of
that's a wonderful and significant story.
The world is a dynamic mess
even Einstein couldn't get his head around it.

It's a world of probabilities.
[Kaku] The Quantum Theory
that's a wonderful and significant story.

[Stephen Hawking]
We need a theory of everything
which is still just beyond our grasp.
We need a theory of everything
that's a wonderful and significant story.
I'll leave you something to imagine!

title: Symphony of Science - the Quantum World!

comments.text:
"God does not play dice", he forms them Universes points on bones which are 
fundamental particles that make up the Big Bang new particles of matter is 
based on a combination of future new universe.

"Бог не играет в кости", он формирует ими Вселенные, точками на костях 
которых служат фундаментальные частицы, Большими взрывами которые образуют 
новые сочетания частиц основ Материи будущей новой Вселенной.﻿
comments.author: Sergey Shevchenko

comments.text:
Came home the other day and my youngest son, Jared, who is significantly 
younger than the rest of my children, was at the table doing his homework. 
 I said hello, he said hello.  I went to get some iced tea and put my feet 
up (I'm a chef, I stand all day), and from the table I hear Jared mumbling 
something as he does his math.

So I stroll on over to hear him sing, in a very low voice, "electrons act 
like waves -- no they don't exactly -- they act like particles -- no they 
don't exactly..." while doing his algebra.

This was one of those "proud dad" moments for me.﻿

comments.author: PhysicsNinja

comments.text:
"Electrons act like waves. No they don't exactly. They act like particles. No they don't exactly."- Richard Feynman

There are some quantum riddles out there. We don't fully understand the universe at the subatomic scale. What's going on with these particles? Unfortunately, assholes take advantage of the gaps in our knowledge and insert their unsupported ideas to fill these gaps. At the same time, there are honest researchers trying to actually understand the workings of the quantum world.

comments.author: Koleksi FLAC

comments.text:
超妙的﻿

lyrics

[Morgan Freeman] 
So, what are we really made of? 
Dig deep inside the atom 
and you'll find tiny particles 
Held together by invisible forces 

Everything is made up 
Of tiny packets of energy 
Born in cosmic furnaces 

[Frank Close] 
The atoms that we're made of have 
Negatively charged electrons 
Whirling around a big bulky nucleus 

[Michio Kaku] 
The Quantum Theory 
Offers a very different explanation 
Of our world 

[Brian Cox] 
The universe is made of 
Twelve particles of matter 
Four forces of nature 

That's a wonderful and significant story 

[Richard Feynman] 
Suppose that little things 
Behaved very differently 
Than anything big 

Nothing's really as it seems 
It's so wonderfully different 
Than anything big 

The world is a dynamic mess 
Of jiggling things 
It's hard to believe 

[Kaku] 
The quantum theory 
Is so strange and bizzare 
Even Einstein couldn't get his head around it 

[Cox] 
In the quantum world 
The world of particles 
Nothing is certain 
It's a world of probabilities 

(refrain) 

[Feynman] 
It's very hard to imagine 
All the crazy things 
That things really are like 

Electrons act like waves 
No they don't exactly 
They act like particles 
No they don't exactly 

[Stephen Hawking] 
We need a theory of everything 
Which is still just beyond our grasp 
We need a theory of everything, perhaps 
The ultimate triump of science 

(refrain) 

[Feynman] 
I gotta stop somewhere 
I'll leave you something to imagine  see less

﻿

[Michio Kaku] 
The Quantum Theory 
Offers a very different explanation 
Of our world 

[Brian Cox] 
The universe is made of 
Twelve particles of matter 
Four forces of nature 

That's a wonderful and significant story 

[Richard Feynman] 
Suppose that little things 
Behaved very differently 
Than anything big 

Nothing's really as it seems 
It's so wonderfully different 
Than anything big 

The world is a dynamic mess 
Of jiggling things 
It's hard to believe 

[Kaku] 
The quantum theory 
Is so strange and bizzare 
Even Einstein couldn't get his head around it 

[Cox] 
In the quantum world 
The world of particles 
Nothing is certain 
It's a world of probabilities 

(refrain) 

[Feynman] 
It's very hard to imagine 
All the crazy things 
That things really are like 

Electrons act like waves 
No they don't exactly 
They act like particles 
No they don't exactly 

[Stephen Hawking] 
We need a theory of everything 
Which is still just beyond our grasp 
We need a theory of everything, perhaps 
The ultimate triump of science 

(refrain) 

[Feynman] 
I gotta stop somewhere 
I'll leave you something to imagine  see less

﻿

comments.text:
Beautiful... stuff... don't stop!

But is the reassuring meme that the universe is made of 12 particles of 
matter still viable in the quantum era where "shit happens"?﻿
comments.author: William Ross

comments.text:
+William Ross Yes it is. The quantum theory doesn't say anything about how 
many fundamental particals there are. It shows us that the very small 
doesn't behave like the very big. For example: you can throw a ball and if 
you know the initial conditions you will know exactly where and when that 
ball will hit the floor. If you make the ball as small as, let's say, an 
electron, you can't predict anything for certain anymore. You can however 
say that it will land at a certain spot 74% of the time. But perhaps 15 % 
it will land somewhere in the opposite direction and 0.001 percent of the 
time it will land a hundred miles further. That is the weirndness of the 
quantum world. However this statistical fact is in a way inversely 
proportional with mass. Therefore of you make the ball big again, the 
chance of it landing anywhere else than predicted is statistically so 
insignificant, that if you throw the ball 1 time per second, the lifetime 
of the universe wouldn't be long enough to probably see it happen just 
once. But it still can... everything is possible

comments.author: Peter Vaňušanik

comments.text:
It makes people feel better when they believe they are not completely in 
control in some cases. It feels nice believing that somewhere, someone is 
watching over you. Be it a guardian angel, a God, anything. Almost every 
culture in the world believed in some sort of deity, spirits, or god(s). It 
doesn't have to be true, but if it makes people feel good, I see no reason 
to tell them otherwise.

Of course, I am talking about the belief in a higher being, not religion. 
Those two are vastly different in my eyes.
comments.author: michelrpg

comments.text:
Because humans need to believe in something greater than themselves for 
existence to be meaningful. Something that transcends the fundamental 
physical particles and waves that include it. In other words the universe 
is meaningless if it doesn't have an essence of some kind.

The universe is all of everything so its essence must be everything as well.
comments.author: neuralshock7

comments.text:
+neuralshock7  Great discussion.Now, you seem reasonable, let me ask you 
this. Why does there have to be a supernatural being who created the 
universe?
comments.author: Iridescent Noise

comments.text:
+Iridescent Noise
And yet the scientists of antiquity had a certain curiosity and drive to 
seek the mysteries of the universe. A need for truth if you will. Trust me 
retaining a love of learning and curiosity is vital to understanding things 
in general. Even one's religion. I'm not saying religion is good or bad, 
only that it helped curious people to develop the skills they needed to 
explore the cosmos for the answers. Studying the Bible is a lot like 
studying nature.

The whole 500 years more advanced is really just speculation rather than 
fact because we don't have time machines and can't change the past. 
Therefore we will never know. Unless of course you claim to have actually 
gone to an alternate universe.

By the way I still consider myself a Christian even if I don't follow the 
Bible to the letter. I honor it in spirit. I believe the universe began in 
a big bang and that humans evolved over eons from countless ape like 
ancestors.
comments.author: neuralshock7

comments.text:
+neuralshock7 Scientists in the past were religious because that was all 
they knew. Everyone was indoctrinated early on. They didn't have nearly as 
much information as we do now.

I grew up in a house with Christianity, but logic never allowed me to 
believe such fantasies. Now days there is so much information that everyone 
can make their own choice rather than have it forced on you.

Were it not for religion it is a known fact that wed be 500 years ahead in 
regards to technology. 

Now with that being said, religion is fine as long as people keep it to 
themselves and out of the judicial system.
comments.author: Iridescent Noise

comments.text:
+Iridescent Noise
Religion is a little more complicated.

Most people are only interested in the stuff having to do with rules, 
punishments, and angry gods. Not the esoteric inner workings of the cosmos 
and the human condition. Why were so many early scientists theologians? 
Because they delved into those mysteries unlike the majority of people who 
didn't give a shit even back then. So you could say that most people are 
actually DISINTERESTED in religion.
